quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Victims and Jack
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, leader, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who wrote the fairy-tale picture-book Shrek, which was later adapted into a computer animated movie?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William Steig

questions.question: Which name refers to a private in the British army?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tommy

questions.question: It was proved that Jack the Ripper raped his victims.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: This name means to gradually diminish.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: peter

questions.question: This common name is also a slang term for a prostitutes customer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John

questions.question: Which of these women was not among the possible victims of Jack the Ripper?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pearly Poll Connelly

questions.question: Who wrote The Last of the Mohicans, an epic novel, featuring the hero Natty Bumppo?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Fenimore Cooper

questions.question: How many murders did Jack the Ripper perpetrate, according to the most widely accepted list of victims?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 5

questions.question: Which of the following refers to a low growing Eurasian shrub of the genus Erica with small evergreen leaves?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Heather

questions.question: What name did the American soldiers in Vietnam use to refer to the Viet Cong collectively?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charlie

questions.question: A good cup of this in the morning goes well with breakfast.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joe

questions.question: Charlemagne was the leader of this Germanic tribe.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Franks

questions.question: What is the title of the last chapter in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, the fourth book in the Harry Potter series?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Beginning

questions.question: This author, recipient of the A. C. Greene Award and the Romance Writers of Americas Lifetime Achievement Award, wrote the novel Unspeakable.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sandra Brown

questions.question: This is also the name of a certain ethnic group in Burma.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Karen

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Following and Profession
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, people, nobleman. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The following is a quote from a letter believed to have been sent by which notorious serial killer to the Central News office in London:
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jack the Ripper

questions.question: Which of the following means a British nobleman ranking right above a viscount and below a marquis?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: earl

questions.question: Studies show that only 30% of all serial murderers are sexually motivated for their actions.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What was Princess Dianas astrological sign?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cancer

questions.question: Which of these people survived the car crash on August 31, 1997 in the Pont de lAlma road tunnel in Paris?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dodi Al-Fayeds bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones

questions.question: Serial killers generally stalk and kill their prey in three ways. Which one of the following is not one of those ways?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Direct

questions.question: What was the profession of Diana Frances Spencer before she became Princess of Wales?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kindergarten teacher

questions.question: Which one of these murderers was once employed by contractor and serial killer John Gacy?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robin Gecht

questions.question: What is the fifth sign of the zodiac?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leo

questions.question: Born in 1960, the son of a prostitute, inflicted from birth with epilepsy, partial paralysis and a deformed right arm, this killer legally changed his name at age 19 to the name of the movie star he idolized.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bruce Lee

questions.question: Between December 1972 and June 1980, authorities in seven southern California counties reported the violent deaths of 21 young men and boys, attributing their murders to The Freeway Killer. What was this murderers name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William George Bonin

questions.question: What are the names of Lady Diana and Prince Charless sons?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William and Harry

questions.question: When did Prince Charles and Princess Diana divorce?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: August 1996

questions.question: While married to Prince Charles, Diana, Princess of Wales, had an affair with James Hewitt. What was his profession?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Her riding instructor

questions.question: The label bad seed related to serial killers personalities derives from William Marchs 1954 novel of the same title.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Woman and Leader
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, john, leader. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Did John pop star icon Denver die October 12, 1997, at the age of 53 in an automobile accident?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: No

questions.question: Princess Diana was buried on an island in the middle of the Round Oval lake in which country estate in England?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Althorp, Northamptonshire

questions.question: In 1997 Lady Diana died in a car crash travelling at high speed in what car?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mercedes-Benz 280 S

questions.question: In 1988 she became the Prime Minister of Pakistan.  She was the first woman to head the government of an Islamic State.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benazir Bhutto

questions.question: She served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990, which makes her the first woman to hold this position in the UK.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Margaret Thatcher

questions.question: Starting in 1966, she was the prime minister of India for 15 years.  Her political career was controversial, as she was viewed by some as a dictator.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Indira Gandhi

questions.question: She was the first black bishop in a major domination, from 1984 until 1988.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leontine T.G. Kelly

questions.question: She was the first recorded female leader. She ruled the Mesopotamian City-State of Ur around 2500 BCE.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ku-Baba

questions.question: Which of these statements refers to the late Diana, Princess of Wales?

options.text: Since the 17th century, Diana was the first English-born spouse of a heir to the English throne.
Diana was the first English princess to omit the word obey in the marriage vows.
In 1987, Diana became the first world-famous celebrity, photographed touching people with AIDS.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: This overweight comedian was, best known for his stint on SNL, was 33 when he died December 18th, 1997.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chris Farley

questions.question: 1974, Argentina.   She became the first ever female president.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Isabel Peron

questions.question: 1960, Sri Lanka.  She became the worlds first female prime minister.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sirimavo Bandaranaike

questions.question: This woman was the first female president of the Philippines. She succeeded her husband after his assassination in 1983, and became the leader of the opposition to President Ferdinand Marcos.  Three years later, she was elected President.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Corazon Aquino

questions.question: Finish the lyrics of Elton Johns song Candle in the Wind 1997 which he performed at Princess Dianas funeral in Westminster Abbey:

options.text: d you whispered to those in pain
And the stars spell out your name.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: And the stars spell out your name.

questions.question: She was the first African American woman to become The United States Secretary of State.  Her name comes from Italian and means to play with sweetness, a musical term.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Condoleezza Rice

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Pirates and U.s.
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, people, piracy. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What President delivered the Gettysburg Address?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Abraham Lincoln

questions.question: Prior to becoming Spy Chief of South Africa in 2001, she was the Minister of Intelligence.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lindiwe Nonceba Sisulu

questions.question: He played the part of Morgan Earp in Gunfight at the O.K. Corral but was probably best known as Bones on Star Trek.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: DeForest Kelly

questions.question: He was Commander of the Continental Army during the War of  Independence and, later ,the first U.S. President to serve two terms.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Washington

questions.question: These establishments sometimes allowed pirates to represent them at times of war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Governments

questions.question: Pirates did not actually have parrots as pets, it is a myth.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What U.S. Presidents campaign slogan was The New Frontier ?  He wanted to get the nation moving again.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Fitzgerald Kennedy

questions.question: The oldest clear definition of piracy was given by the Greek historian Plutarch, around this time.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 100 AD

questions.question: Pirates who operated in the Caribbean were called this.  They were authorized by their governments to attack shipping lines of Christian countries.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Corsairs

questions.question: Who was President during the Suez crisis, after a long career in the U.S. Army?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dwight David Eisenhower

questions.question: This is the name of the pirate flag. The origins of the name are not clear, but the skull and crossbones motif first appeared around 1700.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jolly Roger

questions.question: What U.S. President resigned because of the Watergate affair?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Richard Milhous Nixon

questions.question: What U.S. President is linked with the slogan: America For The Americans?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Monroe

questions.question: It was a popular belief among pirates that a woman aboard the ship brings bad luck.  That is why before becoming a pirate, this woman had to disguise herself as a man.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anne Bonny

questions.question: Which President promoted the Big Stick policy in U.S. foreign matters ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodore Roosevelt

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Team and Pirates
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, people, didnt. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Footballs Iron Man, Brett Farve was a quarterback for which team prior to signing with Green Bay?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Atlanta Falcons

questions.question: New York Mets pitcher Tom Glavine began his baseball career with which team?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Atlanta Braves

questions.question: This Colombian drug lord was arguably the richest and most violent criminal in history.  Forbes Magazine in 1989 listed him as the seventh-richest man in the world.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pablo Escobar

questions.question: This is straight out of the Pirate Code of Conduct.  A pirate found stealing from another member of crew will be punished in this manner.

options.text: He shall be expelled from the ship
He shall be marooned or shot
He shall be left on a deserted island
He shall be given to rival pirates

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He shall be marooned or shot

questions.question: Michael Jordan played for the Chicago Bulls and for two other teams in the NBA.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Roger Clemens has played for which teams in his baseball career?

options.text: Toronto, Boston, New York Yankees, Houston
Chicago White Sox, Texas, New York Yankees, Houston

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Toronto, Boston, New York Yankees, Houston

questions.question: Prince Edward Island was the first Canadian province to prohibit alcohol in 1901. However, these two brothers were famous for smuggling alcohol on their rum running schooner.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Dicks brothers

questions.question: When pirates were caught, they were brought to trial and sentenced to death by hanging.  The hanging was referred to as this.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dancing the hempen jig

questions.question: This smuggler moved to Jamaica after serving a 10-year jail sentence in Canada for importing 75 tons of marijuana into the United States.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Brian ODea

questions.question: Baseball Hall of Famer Ryne Sandburg is best known as a player for the Chicago Cubs. Where else did he play?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Philadelphia

questions.question: NBA superstar Dominique Wilkins played nearly his entire career for Atlanta. What other NBA teams did he also play for?

options.text: Vancouver, Seattle, Boston, Orlando and Houston
Orlando, Boston, New York, Chicago and Miami
Orlando, San Antonio, LA Clippers and Boston
LA Lakers, Orlando, New Jersey and New Orleans

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Orlando, San Antonio, LA Clippers and Boston

questions.question: Pirates were squanderers and didnt have much money to bury.  So the idea of a buried treasure is a romantic one, initiated by Treasure Island.  However, this pirate was known for burying his money.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Captain Kidd

questions.question: Deion Sanders started his football career in San Fransisco.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: These pirates preyed upon cattle and pigs in the areas of Haiti and the Dominican Republic.  Their name comes from the French word for outdoor roast or barbecue.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Buccaneers

questions.question: Which team did English soccer star David Beckham play for before joining Real Madrid in 2003?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Manchester United

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Caligula and Month
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, edict, leader. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Evidence of the longevity of Augustus legacy can be found even today.  For example, the month of August is named after him. What was the Roman name for this month before it was renamed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sextilis

questions.question: Another story tells us about Caligula, declaring war on this Roman god.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Neptune

questions.question: One of the most extravagant and cruel emperors of Rome was Gaius Julius Caesar Germanicus, better known as Caligula. Although there is very little information about his reign, many stories and anecdotes can be heard about Caligula. According to one of them, he tried to make his favourite animal Incitatus, a consul.  What kind of animal was Incitatus?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: horse

questions.question: This man was an international marijuana smuggler who refused to work with hard drugs.  He spent 7 years at the Terre Haute penitentiary in America.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Howard Marks

questions.question: Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus, better known as Caesar Augustus, was the first Roman Emperor (this is true). Although he is known as one of the greatest Roman Emperors, he had some problems with his citizens, as he didnt believe in the Roman Gods.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Commodus had a passion for gladiatorial combat (this is true). He also liked appearing in the arena, dressed as a gladiator.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The rule of Caligula ended in 41 AD with his assassination. Several officers of the Praetorian Guard caught him alone and mercilessly killed him. This man became the next Roman Emperor.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Claudius I

questions.question: Tiberius Caesar Augustus is remembered as a depressed and unpopular ruler, whose reign was marked by terror. Tiberius was into a exile twice - once on the island of Rhodes and the second time on this island.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Capri

questions.question: In 313 AD the Edict of Milan was signed, which made Christianity one of the official religions in the Roman Empire. Years later, Christianity became the official state religion in Rome, under the rule of this emperor.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodosius I

questions.question: One of the most famous buildings of the ancient Rome is the Colosseum. It was built by this Emperor and his son, Titus, between AD 72 and AD 90.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vespasian

questions.question: This American started out as a marijuana smuggler in the 60s making $100,000 per month and eventually became involved in cocaine smuggling on a massive scale.  He is portrayed by Johnny Depp in the movie Blow (2001).
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Jung

questions.question: This man led the Cali Cartel and was a rival of Pablo Escobar.  At its height, the cartel controlled over 80% of the cocaine exports from Colombia to the USA.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gilberto Rodríguez Orejuela

questions.question: The fifth and last Roman Emperor of the Julio-Claudian dynasty was Nero. He was hated by many and he tried to redirect the hatred of the people by persecuting this Eastern sect.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Christians

questions.question: He was the de facto military leader of Panama from 1983 to 1989.  However, in 1992 he was convicted on eight counts of drug trafficking, money laundering and racketeering -- and sentenced to 40 years in federal prison.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Manuel Antonio Noriega Moreno

questions.question: These three brothers were members of the Medellín Cartel. They were influential cocaine kingpins until they surrendered in 1990.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Ochoa brothers
